selected_quotes: Grapiprant in plasma following oral administration higher than164 ng/mL effective in controlling #pain in dogs

citation.abstract:
To assess the effect of food intake on the pharmacokinetics of grapiprant administered orally at 2 mg/kg, and to estimate its oral bioavailability in dogs.
Eight healthy female Labrador Retriever dogs, aged 4-10 years were used. In the initial trial two dogs were administered a 0.5 mg/kg I/V bolus of grapiprant dissolved in ethanol. In the second trial, six dogs were assigned to two treatment groups, using a randomised cross-over design, and received 2 mg/kg of grapiprant orally, as pure powder, after fasting for 12 hours or after being fed. Blood samples were collected at preassigned times up to 36 hours after administration, and concentrations of grapiprant in plasma determined using validated high performance liquid chromatography.
After I/V administration in the two dogs the terminal half life was 5.30 and 6.06 hours, clearance was 444 and 476 mL/hours/kg, and volume of distribution was 3,642 and 3,883 mL/kg. Compared with fasted dogs, oral administration in fed dogs resulted in reduced median peak concentrations in plasma (614 vs. 1,598 ng/mL) and delayed median time of peak concentration (3.0 vs. 1.0 hours). The estimated bioavailability in fasted and fed dogs was 111.9 and 59.1%, respectively. Concentrations of grapiprant in plasma following oral administration, in either fed or fasted dogs, remained higher than 164 ng/mL for up to 6 hours. This concentration has been estimated to be the minimal effective concentration required to control pain in dogs.
Oral administration of 2 mg/kg grapiprant in fed and fasted dogs resulted in different pharmacokinetics of the drug, but did not influence the length of time when concentrations in plasma exceeded theoretical effective concentrations. Further studies are necessary to verify these findings using pharmacokinetic-pharmacodynamic studies and in clinical subjects.
citation.title: Pharmacokinetics and estimated bioavailability of grapiprant, a novel selective prostaglandin E2 receptor antagonist, after oral administration in fasted and fed dogs

author.name: Stefano Cattaneo DVM
author.description: Daily updates about pet health covering the last articles published in veterinary journals.
